items.title: update for Max() & Min() operations
items.body:
Now max(a) returns single value 
a = [10,5,7,8,9,14,2,6,8]
max(a) returns 14

we want something like
a = [10,5,7,8,9,14,2,6,8]
b = [5,15,4,9,7,5,6,12,10]
max(a,b) should return 
[10,15,7,9,9,14,6,12,10]

items.title: not able to use all core of CPU in pandas linux .
items.body:
I am trying to utilize all cores of CPU, for NumPy, I am able to use all cores, but when I am performing some operation in pandas, then again it using only one core of CPU. I have tried to set the max thread and other params, but nothin working foe me. 

eg, 

```
def `a(x):`
  # performing lot of operations  and checks. 

df.groupby(column_A).apply(a).reset_index()
```

**when system is executing Numpy operation, that time CPU is utilization most of the cores, but when it comes to pandas everything is running on single core.**

items.title: Add wheels for Python 3.8
items.body: [Python 3.8.0 has been released for about two months now](https://blog.python.org/2019/10/python-380-is-now-available.html), and [3.8.1 is expected to be released in a few days](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/).

items.title: Slower than numpy
items.body:
Hello !

I need to do something like this  


```
import numpy as np
import numexpr as ne

n = 10000
x, y = np.random.rand(n), np.random.rand(n)

get_ipython().run_line_magic('timeit', '4 * np.sum( np.sqrt(x * x + y *y) <= 1 ) / n')

get_ipython().run_line_magic('timeit', 'ne.evaluate("sum((sqrt(x * x + y *y) <= 1)*1)") * 4 / n')
```

However numexpr is three time slower.

items.title: Add '(not in the build directory)' to the installation manual
items.body:
When following the installation manual as found on:
https://numexpr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user_guide.html#building
to the letter you encounter an 'expected behavior' error (
https://github.com/pydata/numexpr/issues/130).

This is only discovered after doing a google for the error and skipping to the second hit. This time might be saved by adding the text '(not in the build directory)'  in the installation manual.

items.title: NE3: Floordiv operand produces wrong results for small numbers
items.body:
When testing the `//` operand, NE3 produces `-1` for results smaller than the divisor, where the correct result is `0`. 

Example

```python
import numpy as np
import numexpr3 as ne

array = np.arange(20)
print(ne.evaluate("array // 3"))

>> [-1 -1 -1  1  1  1  2  2  2  3  3  3  4  4  4  5  5  5  6  6]
```
**Note the first three results for 0, 1, and 2; respectively**

This is a departure from the result that Numpy gives:

```python
print(array // 3)
>> [0 0 0 1 1 1 2 2 2 3 3 3 4 4 4 5 5 5 6 6]
```

Computer Specs:

 * OS: Windows 7 Enterprise x64 SP 1
* CPU: Intel Core i7-4790

I am working from the `numexpr-3.0` with no modifications.

items.body:
How difficult would it be to add support for unsigned integers?

My use case requires this because I am crunching bits. I'm using shifts and bitwise logic instead of numerical operations.

63 bits is not enough. I need all 64. And if I were in 32 bit mode, I wouldn't want to waste an extra 31 bits by upcasting to 64 bit signed.

items.title: Revert back to limiting number of threads when not explicitely provided
items.body:
The latest `numexpr` patch release (2.6.8 -> 2.6.9) had a change that had a much more important impact than what the changelog describes:
> more robust handling of the thread-setting environment variables

There were an upper bound on the number of threads used before (8) which is not here anymore. A process that was using 8 threads previously can now use up to `<machine CPU count>` threads now! This is even more dramatic when using multiprocessing. If you previously had 8 processes using 8 threads (for a total of 64 threads, which was perfectly fine on a 64 cores machine), with 2.6.9 it is now using 8*64=512 threads.

Considering that `numexpr` is 99% of the time an indirect dependency (from pandas, numpy, etc), which do not enforce patch-level dependency, such high impact changes are potential production-breaking (this happened to us today, for this exact reason).

I don't think convincing other projects to depend on `numexpr` up to patch level is reasonable, so `numexpr` should really try to not have impacting changes without changing at least the minor version.

items.title: Manywheels Builds Generating Errors
items.body:
On trying to build for 2.6.7 release, the Travis side is having issues:

https://github.com/MacPython/numexpr-wheels/

Some Linux builds are erroring and not passing, and some are still erroring but passing...

https://travis-ci.org/MacPython/numexpr-wheels/builds/414659538

Looks like it's some problem with older versions of NumPy (before 1.12.0b1) that permitted negative powers to be applied to integers. I was able to replicate it in a Virtualbox environment. The version check in `expressions.py` isn't working as intended:

    _np_version >= ('1', '12', '0b1')

It won't work for 1.9 or less, as the `'9'` is compared to the `'1'` in the minor version `'12'`.  I'm thinking we should drop the bug-release alphanumeric, and only compare on a 2-element tuple of `(major_ver, minor_ver)` cast to `int`s. The only way the bug-release version would matter if someone was working with an alpha of `numpy` 1.12, which seems unlikely.

items.title: evaluate() generates an extra reference for objects in calling frame
items.body:
I find that `numexpr.evaluate()` generates an extra ref count for objects in calling frame, even when the object isn't used in the expression.  Here's an example:

```python
import numexpr
import numpy as np
import sys

def f():
    a = np.arange(10)
    numexpr.evaluate('1')
    print(sys.getrefcount(a))

def g():
    a = np.arange(10)
    print(sys.getrefcount(a))

f()
g()
```
```
3
2
```

This created a memory leak in my code: in my application, `a` was a big array that I was deleting, but it was never garbage collected because of the reference created by numexpr in a totally unrelated operation.

Notably, passing `local_dict={}` fixes the problem.  I think the usage of `sys._getframe().f_locals` is creating the persistent reference somehow, perhaps via a caching mechanism.  So this code also exhibits the leak:

```python
def h():
    a = np.arange(10)
    sys._getframe(0).f_locals
    print(sys.getrefcount(a))
h()
```

If I had to guess, I'd say this has to do with CPython fast locals (https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Objects/frameobject.c), but I'm not enough of an expert to be able to tell for certain.

If one captures the f_locals dict then calls `clear()` on it, the leak disappears.  I have no idea if this is safe, though!

items.title: Occasional segfault on macOS
items.body:
I'm seeing an intermittent segfault from interpreter.so on macOS, which I suspect may be due to a spurious wakeup from a `pthread_cond_wait` call in `module.cpp`.

Some details (I'm don't have a minimal reproducer yet, but am working on it):

- the segfault occurs approximately one time out of every 20 or so runs of a portion of our application test suite
- the application itself is complex, with many moving parts, including use of PyTables, Qt/PySide, Jupyter and its machinery, etc.
- the crash always comes from one of the `numexpr` worker threads; in all observed cases to date, it coincides with the main thread doing garbage collection (via an explicit `gc.collect()` call)
- the crash occurs in the middle of the test run (i.e., not at process shutdown time, when the Python interpreter is in a dodgy state anyway)
- the code under test, and the test suite, don't actually use `numexpr` at any point beyond importing it. Adding an `import numexpr` to the top of the test suite causes the occasional segfault; removing that import gives us a clean run every time (so far, out of hundreds of runs).
- doing  a `set_num_threads(1)` early on also seems to make the segmentation fault disappear.
- by adding some `printf` calls to the `numexpr` source, it looks as though the segmentation fault coincides with one of the worker threads reaching [this line](https://github.com/pydata/numexpr/blob/8b91a6d0eb4f5ad8a71aceefa17300120272d3c8/numexpr/module.cpp#L68). On successful runs, that line isn't reached by any of the workers (which is what I'd expect, given that `numexpr` isn't actually being used at any point).

I don't know the `numexpr` source at all well, and am only just beginning to grok how it should work, but it's looking to me as though this segfault is the result of a [spurious wakeup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spurious_wakeup) in [this line](https://github.com/pydata/numexpr/blob/8b91a6d0eb4f5ad8a71aceefa17300120272d3c8/numexpr/module.cpp#L59) of code. As far as I can tell, there's no provision for handling spurious wakeups in the module.cpp code.

Can you confirm that the `if (gs.end_threads)` block should never be reached if `numexpr` is imported but unused in a piece of Python code?

Here's the full crash log from macOS

items.title: Pip installation fails
items.body:
I have no idea how long I've been working on this issue and I don't really care. The installation of version 2.6.5 of numexpr using pip 3.7 fails on Windows 10, 64 bit with equivalent Python version 3.7. The error I got was:

Could not install packages due to an EnvironmentError: [WinError 123] The filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect: '"c:'

My PATH variable was set correctly and numpy + mkl 1.14.5 was installed correctly too. In pandas I used the HDF5 storage to save data to disk. This requires tables, which requires numexpr. I'm using the newest version of Visual Studio (2017), I don't know if that's a requirement, but it's there. You'd understand my frustration seeing as I had numexpr installed (and everything seemed to run fine), yet the issue only showed up once I imported and used tables in my script (on ne_compiler.py). I removed and reinstalled every other library thinking the issue was there. 

I ran pip with the --log option, the data is below. The binary pre-compiled version of numexpr runs fine.

items.title: Numexpr 3 language scope
items.body:
Do you have a document specifying the names of all the functions and operators in numexpr 3? (Including constants like `e` and `pi`: do you recognize these names or do they have to be in scope? In aggressive mode, which powers do you replace with explicit multiplication? Etc.)

I'm developing a histogramming package (https://github.com/diana-hep/histbook) that takes expressions as quantities to evaluate and plot (could address your #205). These expressions look a lot like numexpr and could benefit from being exactly the same language as numexpr (my [#22](https://github.com/diana-hep/histbook/issues/22) and [#23](https://github.com/diana-hep/histbook/issues/23). For instance, I should rename my "asin" to "arcsin" for complete compatibility.

But I see that you're in preparation for a big release, so I should probably aim for compatibility with the new version. Do you have a specification?

Thanks!

items.title: Why in my case numexpr.evaluate() slower than eval()?
items.body:
The purpose of using the numexpr.evaluate() is to speed up the compute. But im my case it wokrs even slower than numpy und eval(). I would like to know why?

code for test:
```python
import datetime
import numpy as np
import numexpr as ne

expr = '11808000.0*1j*x**2*exp(2.5e-10*1j*x) + 1512000.0*1j*x**2*exp(5.0e-10*1j*x)'


# use eval
start_eval = datetime.datetime.now()
namespace = dict(x=np.array([m+3j for m in range(1, 1001)]), exp=np.exp)
result_eval = eval(expr, namespace)
end_eval = datetime.datetime.now()
# print(result)
print("time by using eval   : %s" % (end_eval- start_eval))


# use numexpr
# ne.set_num_threads(8)
start_ne = datetime.datetime.now()
x = np.array([n+3j for n in range(1, 1001)])
result_ne = ne.evaluate(expr)
end_ne = datetime.datetime.now()
# print(result_ne)
print("time by using numexpr: %s" % (end_ne- start_ne))
```
return: 
time by using eval : ___0:00:00.002998
time by using numexpr: 0:00:00.052969

items.title: Keep `is_cpu_amd_intel` variable?
items.body: I recently got news that [is_cpu_amd_intel variable is gone from numexpr](https://github.com/PyTables/PyTables/pull/685).  Although PyTables was not using this variable directly, it was importing it explicitly, and getting rid of it would create more havoc than strictly necessary.  @robbmcleod do you think this can be back again in numexpr for the next release?  We would really appreciate this.

items.title: Processes are spawned while loading
items.body:
My main process gets spawned on multiple cores when I say "import numexpr", even if my code does not use the module anywhere. If I run htop to analyze resource usage for my main task, the memory usage/amount of memory reserved gets split up into multiple tasks, just because the module is imported.
[Edit] Attached below are the snapshots from htop output, the sub-process remain in "Sleep" state all the time, and only the parent process keeps "Running".

items.title: Test bench doesn't run on Python 3
items.body: The test bench `numexpr/tests/test_numexpr.py` does not run on Python 3 interpreters due to some old Python 2 types -like long- used along its code.

items.title: Behaviour change of numexpr; NaN instead of 0
items.body:
Hi,

I am not sure whether this is a `numexpr` issue, or rather a `mkl` or even a `numpy` issue. However, I think the most likely case is `numexpr`.

My pytest CI suite threw a lot of errors in my last run. Digging into it I could boil it down to this minimal example:

    import numpy as np
    from numexpr import evaluate
    test = np.array([-1-1j])*np.infty
    out1 = np.exp(test)
    out2 = evaluate("exp(test)")
    print(' PRINT OUT RESULT ::', out1, out2)

Doing this evaluation with `numpy`, hence `np.exp(test)`, results in `[ 0.-0.j]`. This result was also returned by `numexpr`, until recently. Now, `numexpr` returns `[nan+nanj]`.

I attach below the result for the above minimal example  (saved as `test_numexpr.py`). I run the test first with the up-to-date conda, where `numpy` and `numexpr` yield different results. Then I downgrade `mkl` from 2018 to 2017, which also slightly downgrades `numexpr`. With the older versions `numexpr` and `numpy` yield the same result:

    test/> python test_numexpr.py
    PRINT OUT RESULT :: [ 0.-0.j] [ nan+nanj]

    test/> conda install mkl=2017

    Fetching package metadata ...............
    Solving package specifications: .

    Package plan for installation in environment ~/anaconda3/envs/test_36:

    The following packages will be DOWNGRADED:

        mkl:     2018.0.0-hb491cac_4   --> 2017.0.4-h4c4d0af_0
        numexpr: 2.6.2-py36hdd3393f_1  --> 2.6.2-np113py36_0  
        numpy:   1.13.3-py36ha12f23b_0 --> 1.13.1-py36_0      
        scipy:   1.0.0-py36hbf646e7_0  --> 0.19.1-np113py36_0 

    test/> python test_numexpr.py
    PRINT OUT RESULT :: [ 0.-0.j] [ 0.-0.j]

Any ideas on that?

Thanks,
Dieter

items.title: How to cache intermediate values?
pkg_resources causes a slow import; any way to avoid?
items.body:
The use of pkg_resources.parse_version (see #162) causes the import time of numexpr to slow down significantly, from approx 0.4 seconds without pkg_resources.parse_version to 2.1 seconds with pkg_resources.parse_version.

(perhaps I should note that I am not a direct consumer of numexpr and have never used it, but pandas does and I use pandas)

Please consider alternate methods... if there are any.

The culprit is in expressions.py

```
import numpy
from pkg_resources import parse_version
_np_version = parse_version(numpy.__version__)
```

(my "speedup" was to comment out those last two lines referencing parse_version and substitute `_np_version = '1.12.1'` just to see how this impacts import time)

----

(see also https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/510)

items.title: control number of threads on import
items.body:
hi numexpr folks

I have an issue with numexpr, where it is running in a shared environment with thread limits imposed by a scheduler

when i import numexpr, it appears to run `detect_number_of_threads`
https://github.com/pydata/numexpr/blob/master/numexpr/__init__.py#L49
then `set_num_threads`
https://github.com/pydata/numexpr/blob/master/numexpr/__init__.py#L61
as part of the import.  I can't find a way to control this until after I have imported the module

However, the scheduler is setting a thread limit based on resource usage, which is often much lower than that returned by `detect_number_of_threads`
This causes the job to fail before it has got going and before I have `numexpr` imported into my python session to enable me to reduce the number of threads to use.  

So, I am looking for a way to control this thread pool size prior to importing numexpr;
is there any help or advice you can offer?

thank you
mark

items.title: NE3: Support AArch64
items.body:
`pip install blosc` on aarch64 / python3.5.2 errors out due to cpuinfo.py not having a match clause for aarch64.

This is solvable by adding the following three lines:

```
+       elif re.match('^aarch64$', raw_arch_string):
+               arch = 'AARCH_64'
+               bits = 64
```

Cheers!
Ian

items.title: NE3: Thread pool manager object
items.body:
Currently the array space for temporaries is `PyMalloc`ed individually for each thread once per call to `NumExpr_run()`.  A faster solution would be to take the approach of NumPy and have a pre-allocated pool that could be assigned for the temporaries for each thread by a manager, hooked into the global state.  Such a system would also be easier to verify that it does not leak memory.

At present `NPY_MAX_ARGS` == 32, so the maximum space that could be allocated to temporaries would be approximately `32*4096*N_THREADS*ITEMSIZE`, so for 8 threads and `float64` the pre-allocated space would be a maximum of 8.4 MB of RAM.

items.title: NE3: Pickling of C-NumExpr object
items.body:
Currently the C-NumExpr object cannot be pickled.  Pickling of the C-NumExpr object would permit serialization of the module.  This could be valuable in two cases: 1.) Pickling of the wisdom (formally cache) dictionary, which stores all the compiled programs.  This could speed loading of pre-optimized Python code by a wisdom bank functionality similar to that seen in FFTW.  2.) Serialization within the context of parallel processes, as within the `multiprocessing` module or similar.  This could potentially allow for parallel processing libraries (`dask`, etc.) to use NE3 in a hybrid multi-processing/multi-threading environment, similar to the way OpenMPI hybrid mode permits the same.  Thus NE3 could leverage the RAM conservation and memory sharing of threads, while multiple processes are spawned in distributed/cluster environments.

The main issue as I see it is how to accommodate the constants.  These are the only components outside of `NumExprProgram` and `NumExprRegister` that are created in `NumExpr_init`, as the temporaries are initialized in the interpreter itself.  Practically we should investigate if the constant arrays really need to be BLOCK_SIZE in shape.  I suspect if a singleton array is broadcast with a multi-dimensional NumPy array, that a stride of zero is returned. In Python an empty tuple is returned; it remains to be seen what the C-API returns.  In this case, the BLOCK_SIZE shaped const is really a waste of L1 cache space.

items.title: NE3: Striding of complex_functions.hpp
items.body:
This one is easy, we need the complex functions to have a separate branch for strided operations.  This can be done in the same was as `real_functions.cpp`.  Note that `.real` and `.imag` return strided `float` views of the underlying `complex` array.

One concern unveiled in testing is that complex division with `float32` yields different values between NumExpr3 and NumPy.  The implementation of NumExpr3’s complex division is naïve. Most higher precision complex division algorithms, such as Smith’s algorithm, are branched based on the complex phase of the involved numbers.  Ideally we would prefer a branchless algorithm, if one can be sourced, as it is likely to be much faster within the confines of vectorized operations.

items.title: NE3: Refactorization of test submodule
items.body:
The `tests` submodule needs to be rebuilt to accommodate the changes made relative to NE2, in particular, the closer conformance to the NumPy standards and the greater subset of the Python language supported, in particular assignment.  

With NE3 we have now introduced the idea of a generated ‘autotest’ component as well, which compares individual NumExpr operations and functions to their NumPy equivalents, to ensure that NE3 produces equivalent results to NumPy.  

Also NE3 supports a number of functions in `scipy.special`, however that module is not a dependency of NumExpr (and should not be).  In this case we should use conditional test imports of `scipy.special` and only generate test code for the special functions if it is present.  This will avoid breaking continuous integration while still allowing most end-users to test these functions.  

This issue has high priority.

items.title: NE3: Crash with Python 3.6
items.body:
On Window 7 with Anaconda Python 3.6, there is a crash within `pthread.c` after the second call to the interpreter.  Crash occurs inside the function `pthread_cond_wait` inside the parallel branch of `vm_engine_iter_parallel`, upon the call to:

`WaitForSingleObject(cond->sema, INFINITE);`

Official documentation is not very illuminating:

https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms687032(v=vs.85).aspx

`cond` is definitely not `NULL` and `cond->sema` seems to have a reasonable integer for its object handle.  So this one is a bit of a mystery. 

I compiled with MSVC14.0.  Error does not occur with Python 3.5.  I wonder if the compilation environment variables for Python 3.6 have been changed?  I couldn't find any information on python.org.

items.title: support for inplace addition/subtraction/multiplication to `out` keyword?
items.body:
In a lot of my codes, I want to perform several inplace additions to the same array of data. For example, I may try to evaluate a function `f(x) =g(x)+ h(x)  + k(x)` where k(x), g(x), and h(x) can possibly be expressed in numexpr. Ideally, I could avoid all intermediate allocation be doing something like

```
f = np.zeros(shape)
inplace_funcion_not_numexpr(f)
ne.evaluate(expr1, out=f, inplace_op='+')
ne.evaluate(expr2, out=f, inplace_op='+')
ne.evaluate(expr3, out=f, inplace_op='+')
```

Is this possible using numexpr?

items.title: String processing in numexpr
items.body: I find the bcolz/numexpr combination very powerful. I sometimes process strings in huge bcolz ctables and I dream of numexpr supporting string operations such as concatenation, left, split, ... as efficiently as for numerical and Boolean data. For example, Iworked some time ago on the Avito Context Ad click competition on Kaggle https://www.kaggle.com/c/avito-context-ad-clicks/data and I was unable to efficiently process  the `Params ` attribute in `AdsInfo` table, or `SearchQuery `and `SearchParams `in `SearchInfo ` table.

items.title: 2.6.0 about 25% slower than 2.5.2 with MKL
items.body:
I performed some benchmark comparisons using the WinPython distribution  at https://winpython.github.io/
Like Anaconda on Windows, WinPython uses numexpr and numpy compiled with MKL from wheels on this web site: www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/

I used the following benchmark script on my Haswell Core i7-4700HQ-based Windows 8.1 PC, which is dominated by numexpr and representative of the way I typically use numexpr:

```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
import numpy as np
import numexpr as ne
from timeit import default_timer as timer

x = np.ones(100000)
scaler = -1J
start = timer()
for k in range(10000):
    cexp = ne.evaluate('exp(scaler * x)')
exec_time=(timer() - start)
print
print("Execution took", str(round(exec_time, 3)), "seconds")
```

I got the same performance for Python 3.4 and 3.5 environments.  With numexpr 2.5.1 and 2.5.2, I got 7.3 seconds.  With numexpr 2.6.0, I got 9.1 seconds, which 25% slower.

My test environment can be reproduced from the following distribution installers:
numexpr 2.5.1 from WinPython-64bit-3.4.4.2.exe at https://sourceforge.net/projects/winpython/files/WinPython_3.4/3.4.4.2/
numexpr 2.6.0 from WinPython-64bit-3.4.4.3rc.exe at https://sourceforge.net/projects/winpython/files/WinPython_3.4/3.4.4.3/betas/

The list of changed packages is available here:
https://github.com/winpython/winpython/issues/309

items.title: Numexpr evaluate function returns zero arrays when running on Xeon processors
items.body:
Hello. I've recently discovered what appears to be a bug in Numexpr.

In a nutshell, `evaluate` sometimes (unpredictably) returns incorrect results when doing a straightforward array operation. The bug, which can be reproduced by the code below, results in a zero array being returned rather than the correct result. Although the sample code shows a multiplication, this bug has manifested for us on addition and exponentiation as well. Notably, there are no errors or warnings that are raised by Numexpr, the computational load appears normal (i.e. the RAM and CPU are taxed as expected when monitoring task manager), and the correct shape array is returned. It was a rather insidious bug to isolate for those reasons! In our tests, this bug has only manifested in the following hardware builds:
1. Windows Server 2012 r2, Intel Xeon 2680 v3,
   2 processors, 48 logical cores
2. Windows 8.1, Intel Xeon 2690,
   1 processor, 24 logical cores

In all the many thousands of runs of our software completed on our Windows 7, 64 bit, Intel i7 machines, this has never manifested. Furthermore, we have run the attached code many times (with bigger arrays and more iterations) and have not seen the error on the Windows 7, i7 machines. The Xeon computers, though, manifest it regularly. Unfortunately we don't have any other builds on which to test.

Any advice you have would be greatly appreciated. We have come to depend on Numexpr to do efficient multiprocessing on basic array operations in Python. The possibility of this error manifesting during a long run, though, without any kind of raised error or warning, is very problematic. 

Other items of note:
1. We are running from the WinPython distribution 3.4.3.6 and included Numexpr 2.4.4.
2. We have not invoked any supporting Numexpr functions, just `evaluate`... so we are using its default settings.

Thank you so much for writing such a useful tool, and thank you in advance for any help you can give us.

Sample Code:

```
import numpy as np
import numexpr as ne

x = np.ones(1e6)
y = np.ones(1e6)

for ii in range(1000):

    rr = ne.evaluate('x * y')
    test = np.all(rr == 0)
    if test:
        print('Gotcha! %d' % ii)

print('Complete!')
```

items.title: __getattr__ raises KeyError, should be AttributeError
Out directly on indexed ndarray with mask
items.body:
Hello,

"data1", "data2" and "mask" have the same shape a "result".
mask is a boolean mask for indexing.

Out on an intermediate ndarray and copy on final indexed array: work good. 

``` python
    result = np.zeros((100, 100))  # Create result array with good shape
    d1, d2 = data1[mask], data2[mask]  # Select data to compute only with mask
    result[mask] = ne.evaluate('d1**d2')  # compute with numexpr
```

Out directly on final indexed array: don't work.

``` python
    result = np.zeros((100, 100))  # Create result array with good shape
    d1, d2 = data1[mask], data2[mask]  # Select data to compute with mask
    ne.evaluate('d1**d2', out=result[mask])  # compute with numexpr.
```

items.title: Non-deterministic calculating issue
items.body:
I don't know why this is happening but sometimes my evaluate gives 0.0 for the output of something that should be about 1.0 about 92 times in 3000 executions. I would love to get the right answer every time, if possible. My test code is

```
from numexpr import evaluate
import numpy as np

failure = 0
for n in range(3000):
    x = np.ones((1500, 1500), dtype=np.complex128)
    X = evaluate('x.real * x.real + x.imag * x.imag', local_dict={'x': x})
    if X[0, 0] < 0.5:
        failure += 1

print('numexpr failed ' + str(failure) + ' times out of 3000')
```

My platform is Anaconda python=3.4 for Win64. The relevant package versions are
numexpr: 2.4.4-np19py34_p0 [mkl]
mkl:     11.1-np19py34_p1
numpy:   1.9.3-py34_p0     [mkl]

I have run this code on two different intel processors from two years ago and more like 7 years ago and I get the same behavior. The number of failures and their order are never the same.

items.title: Math errors in version 2.4.4 in Windows 10
items.body:
I'm getting bizarre and random mathematical errors when running version 2.4.4 on a Windows 10 machine. For example, `exp(n)` is yielding _negative numbers_ , or a call to `pandas.eval()` on a boolean expression will yield all False. Suffice to say, it is critically broken. What is even more frustrating is that the problem occurs randomly: I will run my program and it will crash in an early step; when I re-run it again, it will crash in a completely different step. 

I haven't had much luck reproducing the problem from a Notebook environment, however I have access to two Windows 10 machines and they both exhibited the same behaviour running the exact same code on the exact same version of `numexpr`. When I downgrade to Version 2.4.3, the problem completely goes away. Furthermore, version 2.4.4 works just fine on my Windows 7 machine, so this appears to be specific to Win 10. 

Any help would be much appreciated.

items.title: calculation error : NUMEXPR 2.4.4, Python 3.4.3, Pandas 0.17 or 0.16.x, Windows 7/10 64bit
items.body:
When numexpr is available to pandas the first two rows of a pandas dataframe have incorrect values. When I remove numexpr availability to Pandas the values are computed correctly.

Operation 1 (copy) data, values are correct
Operation 2 (add) values in first two rows are set to a small values (e.g.) 2.4-312.

df['new']=df['a'].copy()
df['new']=+10.0 

Using numpy directly produces correct result.
Using pandas without numexpr produces correct result.
Using pandas with numexpr produces erroneous results.

I see the same type of result for multiplication. It only affects the first two rows in dataframe.

===VERIFIED 2.4.3 works!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

100 test runs

The issue with high probability is with numexpr 2.4.4

items.title: Regression from 2.4.3 to 2.4.4
items.body:
I have the following piece of code:

```
import numexpr as ne
import numpy as np

x1, x2 = [np.random.rand(100000) for i in (0, 0)]

prev = None
for i in range(10000):
    d = ne.evaluate("x1 - x2")
    if prev is None:
        pass
    elif np.any(np.abs(prev - d) > 1e-10):
        print("Step", i, "Sums:", np.sum(prev), "vs.", np.sum(d))
        break
    prev = d
```

I'm essentially taking the difference of two random vectors and finding that after repeating that for some time the difference changes significantly.

This code runs fine with numexpr-2.4.3, I'm using Anaconda on Windows AMD64 with the newest version of NumPy (1.10, 1.9 showed the same problem though), and the problem only appears when running multithreaded. Can someone else reproduce this?

It seems like a threading issue that leads to parts of the difference array being values very close to zero (~1e-315).

items.title: Numexpr fails to install from source
items.body:
From a fresh install (or virtualenv), numexpr fails to install from source. The following error occurs:

``` shell
$ python setup.py install
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 223, in <module>
    setup_package()
  File "setup.py", line 62, in setup_package
    from numpy.distutils.core import setup
ImportError: No module named numpy.distutils.core
```

Specifically the Line 62 in setup.py (https://github.com/pydata/numexpr/blob/master/setup.py#L62) presumes numpy is already installed before even running `setup` itself. I doubt this was intended since numpy is also listed inside `setup_requires`.

This issue seems to be related to https://github.com/PyTables/PyTables/issues/454
